awd_titl_txt: FRG:  Collaborative Research:  Crossing the Walls in Enumerative Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This project concerns the field of algebraic geometry, a branch of mathematics studying the geometric structure of solutions of polynomial equations. Many of the questions under study in this project are motivated by string theory, a branch of theoretical physics connected with the structure of elementary particles. This project aims to significantly enhance the intensive and fruitful interaction between cutting edge research in enumerative algebraic geometry and theoretical physics. The research aims to extend mathematical developments that verify and generalize conjectures originating from physics, and the work is expected to significantly impact development of the physical theory as well. Through conferences, a summer school, seminars, and research involvement, this project provides unique opportunities for a new generation of mathematicians to obtain the interdisciplinary knowledge and skills needed to work in this exciting research area.

The aim of the project is to study enumerative invariants in the broad sense and their dependence on various stability conditions, as well as dualities relating different enumerative invariants. The investigators plan to further develop the theory of Gauged Linear Sigma Models (GLSM) and will study the epsilon-wall-crossing conjecture and zeta-wall-crossing conjecture at all genera; Gromov-Witten (GW) and quasimap invariants are related by a sequence of epsilon-wall-crossing, whereas the Calabi-Yau/Landau-Ginzburg correspondence (relating GW invariants and FJRW invariants) and Pfaffian/Grassmannian correspondence are examples of zeta-wall-crossing. The investigators are developing the theory of Mixed-Spin-P (MSP) fields, to interpolate GW theory of quintic threefolds and FJRW theory of Fermat quintic polynomials, and to study algebraic structures of higher genus GW and FJRW invariants. The new theories of GLSM and MSP fields will provide new tools to attack the central and longstanding problem of computing higher genus GW invariants of compact Calabi-Yau threefolds. The investigators have been investigating K-theoretic Donaldson-Thomas invariants of threefolds, as well as GW and quasimap invariants of Nakajima quiver varieties. Because some of conjectures motivated by theoretical physics can only be properly formulated in terms of K-theoretic enumerative invariants, they plan to study dualities relating K-theoretic enumerative invariants of different geometries, and to lift results on traditional enumerative invariants to the K-theoretic setting.

por.por_cntn:
We study enumerative invariants in the broad sense and their dependence on various stability conditions (wall-crossing), as well as dualities relating different enumerative theories (crossing the walls).  Gromov-Witten (GW) theory,  quasimap theory, Donaldson-Thomas (DT) theory, and Pandharipande-Thomas (PT) theory are defined by virtual fundamental classes on moduli spaces of stable maps, stable quasimaps, ideal sheaves, and stable pairs, respectively; their K-theoretic enhancements are defined by virtual structure sheaves, which can be viewed as categorication of virtual fundamental classes, on the corresponding moduli spaces. GW and PT invariants are related by GW/PT correspondence, while DT and PT invariants are related by wall-crossing.

The project has produced the following significant results on K-theoretic and cohomological enumerative invariants, wall-crossing, and dualities relating different enumerative theories: a direct inductive proof of the existence and uniqueness of stable envelopes in equivariant elliptic cohomology in a rather general setting, and applications to equivariant K-theoretic enumeration of quasimaps, including computation of vertex functions and their monodromy in the space of geometric invariant theory (GIT) stability conditions; an explicit formula for the stationary GW/PT descendant correspondence in terms of vertex operators, and Virasoro constraints for stationary PT descendent invariants, are proposed for general non-singular projective 3-folds and proved in the toric case; formulation of a two-parameter generalization of the geometric Langlands correspondence and proof of the correspondence for all simply-laced Lie algebras; proof of open/closed correspondence relating open GW invariants counting holomorphic disks in symplectic toric Calabi-Yau 3-folds and closed GW invariants counting holomorphic spheres in symplectic toric Calabi-Yau 4-folds.

The project has trained a group of graduate students, including more than ten PhDs completed during 2016-2021 and five PhDs in progress. The training activities include topic courses taught by the investigators and weekly seminars organized by the investigators. The PI was the lead organizer of the Spring 2018 MSRI program "Enumerative Geometry Beyond Numbers", and taught a 33-lecture online course on enumerative geometry and geometric representation theory during the pandemic. The award has provided funding for a workshop in 2017, weekly seminars, participation of conferences, and visits for collaboration. The award also partially supported a conference and a 5-week program in 2022.
